summary: This document contains press guidance from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York regarding the trial of Ghislaine Maxwell. It provides logistical details for court proceedings on November 26, 2021, notes that several witnesses will testify under pseudonyms to protect victim identities, and lists the statutory maximum penalties Maxwell faces on six charges related to conspiring with Jeffrey Epstein to sexually exploit minors.

keyFacts: The court ruled that several government witnesses, who are not alleged victims themselves, may testify under pseudonyms to protect the identities of alleged victims.
Ghislaine Maxwell faced six charges with statutory maximum penalties totaling up to 65 years in prison, with the most severe being conspiracy to commit sex trafficking of minors (40 years max).
The charges explicitly state Maxwell conspired with Jeffrey Epstein to entice and transport minors for illegal sexual activity.
Government exhibits for the trial were provided exclusively through an SDNY file share, and media were directed to use PACER for case filings.
The press guidance emphasizes media policies against identifying sex crime victims without consent and urges respect for witness privacy.
